title: Verify when Uncertain: Beyond Self-Consistency in Black Box Hallucination Detection
author: Yihao Xue (University of California, Los Angeles), Kristjan Greenewald (MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab), Youssef Mroueh (IBM Research), Baharan Mirzasoleiman (University of California, Los Angeles), ...
relevance_why: This paper's exploration of hallucination detection methods has potential applications in audio and speech domains, especially in ensuring the accuracy of generated content.
background: The paper addresses hallucinations in large language models (LLMs), where generated responses appear plausible but contain inaccuracies, particularly in black-box settings.
contribution: This paper introduces a budget-friendly, two-stage detection algorithm that combines self-consistency and cross-model consistency with verifier models to improve hallucination detection performance.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods have primarily relied on self-consistency-based approaches that are close to ceiling performance.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work advances detection by integrating a verifier model, demonstrating improved performance over self-consistency alone.

key_innovation: The method uniquely balances computational efficiency with improved detection accuracy through selective use of cross-model consistency.
real_world_impact: The proposed approach could enhance the reliability of LLMs in practical applications across various domains, potentially reducing the risks associated with misinformation.
limitations: The necessity for model selection and the computational overhead for the verifier model could restrict usability in certain contexts.

new_terms.black-box setting: **Black-box setting** refers to scenarios where the internal workings of the model are not accessible, and only the inputs and outputs are observable.
